awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel handheld spectroscopy for the early detection of crop afflictions
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will focus on development of a handheld optical scanner that integrates precise imaging with optical spectroscopy.  Although this technology has broad applications ranging from industrial quality control to education, the beachhead sector to be addressed is precision agriculture. To feed a growing population of 10 billion in 2050, agricultural production will need to increase by 70% over the next 30 years. Critical to this mission is the development of innovative tools and strategies for crop protection and health management to preserve the world’s food supply. The potential customers in this segment are crop growers, consultants, and field scouts aiming to act early while reducing the use of harmful and costly chemicals. The global crop monitoring market was estimated at $2 billion in 2019 and is anticipated to reach $6 billion by 2027, growing at 15.3% annually. The sensing and imaging segment accounted for 49.3% of the market in 2019. This technology has the potential to support the adoption of more sustainable agricultural practices as well as the economic viability of small- to medium-scale farm operations in the U.S. by providing an accessible and affordable tool for disease detection and crop health management.

The intellectual merit of this project is the commercial development of novel and affordable imaging spectroscopy technology in addition to application-specific analytics for the early detection of crop afflictions. Optical components of the scanning device that will be designed-for-manufacturing in this project bridge the current gap created by systems that trade the detection capabilities of spectral resolution for spatial resolution. The scanner will be deployed to collect data on grapes, a key, high-value crop that is susceptible to a number of afflictions that destroy yields before the human eye can detect them. Machine learning algorithms will be developed from this data to detect stressed and diseased states in the plant before they become apparent to visual inspection. These models will then be validated in the field with user feedback from horticultural experts and customers. Successful implementation of this technology will facilitate the detection of crop diseases before they spread. This detection capability can increase yields while reducing the use of costly and environmentally-harmful pesticides and fertilizers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report: Early Disease Detection for Healthier Crops Using Novel Optical Spectroscopy

Award Number: 2213137

Project Summary:

Advanced Growing Resources (AGR) has developed a revolutionary technology, called Spectre, that helps farmers detect crop diseases before they become visible to the naked eye. Imagine a doctor being able to diagnose an illness days or even weeks before a patient feels sick - that's what Spectre does for plants. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation's Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) program, focused on creating a handheld device that uses advanced chemical signature analysis via optical spectroscopy to identify problems like powdery mildew, nutrient deficiencies, and water stress in grapevines.

Traditionally, farmers rely on visual inspection or time-consuming lab tests to diagnose plant diseases. By the time a problem is visible, it's often too late for effective treatment, leading to significant crop losses and the overuse of fungicides and fertilizers. Spectre changes this by providing a fast, accurate, and non-contact way to see the subtle changes in a plant's light signature that indicate stress or disease.

Intellectual Merit (Scientific Advancements):

The core innovation lies in combining a highly sensitive, miniature spectrometer with sophisticated machine learning algorithms. The spectrometer captures the unique chemical fingerprint of a leaf, analyzing how it reflects wavelengths of light beyond what the human eye and standard cameras can see. This fingerprint changes subtly when a plant is stressed or infected, even before visible symptoms appear. Our machine learning models, trained on thousands of leaf scans from healthy and diseased plants, can then interpret these subtle changes to accurately diagnose the problem.

Key scientific achievements include:

  • High Accuracy: Our system achieved over 97% accuracy in detecting powdery mildew, a common and devastating grapevine disease.

  • Early Detection: Spectre can identify powdery mildew infection up to 8 days before visual symptoms appear, and 5 times earlier than trained human observers. This provides a critical window for preventative treatment.

  • Multi-Stress Detection: The system can also diagnose water stress and nutrient deficiencies simultaneously, providing a comprehensive plant health assessment.

  • Miniaturization and Portability: We've created a truly handheld device, smaller than a smartphone, that's easy to use in the field.

  • Modular Design: The spectrometer's design allows for flexibility and upgrades, supporting future expansion to other crops and diseases.

  • Data-Driven Approach: We built a large, validated dataset of spectral signatures for various grapevine conditions, and developed a robust machine learning pipeline for analysis.

Broader Impacts (Societal Benefits):

Spectre has the potential to transform agriculture, benefiting farmers, consumers, and the environment. By enabling early and targeted interventions, it promotes:

  • Increased Farm Profitability: Early detection allows farmers to apply treatments only when and where needed, reducing the use of expensive fungicides and fertilizers. This translates to lower costs and higher yields of healthier crops.

  • Reduced Chemical Use: By minimizing unnecessary spraying, Spectre helps protect the environment, reducing the impact on beneficial insects, soil health, and water quality. It supports a shift towards more sustainable farming practices.

  • Improved Food Security: By preventing crop losses, Spectre helps ensure a more stable and abundant food supply.

  • Enhanced Food Quality: Early detection of nutrient deficiencies and water stress leads to healthier plants and higher-quality produce.

  • Support for Small Farms: Spectre is an affordable and accessible tool that can benefit small- to medium-scale farms, helping them compete and thrive.

  • Economic Growth: By advancing digital agriculture technologies, this project helps create a competitive U.S. agricultural economy that can support local production.
